headline.main: Text to Text | ‘The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks’ and ‘The Sequel’

docs.abstract: We invite students to explore the science and ethics of using human cells and tissue for medical research through the lens of Rebecca Skloot’s 2010 book, “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks,” and a related 2013 Op-Ed.
docs.snippet: We invite students to explore the science and ethics of using human cells and tissue for medical research through the lens of Rebecca Skloot’s 2010 book, “The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks,” and a related 2013 Op-Ed.

keywords.value: The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks (Book)
keywords.name: creative_works

byline.original: By JENNIFER CUTRARO, SARAH GROSS and THE LEARNING NETWORK

docs.lead_paragraph: Gut checks suggest that not having enough of certain "good" intestinal germs early in life may increase babies' risk of developing asthma, according to a new study of more than 300 children.

headline.main: Study: Good Gut Bacteria May Affect Babies' Risk of Asthma
headline.print_headline: Study: Good Gut Bacteria May Affect Babies' Risk of Asthma

docs.snippet: Gut checks suggest that not having enough of certain "good" intestinal germs early in life may increase babies' risk of developing asthma, according to a new study of more than 300 children.

docs.lead_paragraph: The program, which will use sensors embedded in desk lamps, is the latest in a series of initiatives by the city and state to protect salon workers from dangerous work conditions and labor abuses.

headline.main: Pilot Program Will Gauge Air Quality in New York Nail Salons
headline.print_headline: Air Quality in Nail Salons to Be Tested

docs.abstract: New York City public advocate's office introduces pilot program that will install air quality sensors in nail salons across city to determine whether chemical levels in air are safe; program is backed by Clinton Global Initiative, and is latest step of many undertaken by city to protect nail salon workers in wake of article series in The New York Times.
docs.snippet: The program, which will use sensors embedded in desk lamps, is the latest in a series of initiatives by the city and state to protect salon workers from dangerous work conditions and labor abuses.
